title: Reporting V3 Epic
body:
Existing reporting issues are tagged here
https://github.com/diffgram/diffgram/labels/reporting

Other issues I'll bullet point here to group together

Recent regressions / changes
- [ ] Re-Adding formatting for Time Tracking
e.g. Display what is on x-axis and y-axis. i.e. Average of seconds per annotation on y axis, date on x-axis
- [ ] Clarify timezone or display time in local time zone
- [ ] Double group by colors (randomly assigned) don't align (legend and dataset) after refresh. Something to do with how chart js loads probably. 

- [ ] TaskTimeTracking related reports have been integrated into Reporting directly, 
this should mostly deprecate AnnotatorPerformanceReport and TimeSpentReport but they have not been removed. See next point
- [ ] Extending the new InitQuery class concept to work with predefined reporting classes, sort of in the direction of the 
The main idea each reporting class defines it's own class specific logic, using InitQuery and new concepts as needed.
So instead of current state of those classes having a single run() function, they could instead have things like `self.init_query.base`, `apply_filters()`, `format_results`, `define_format` etc.
More on this in other docs / see Anthony
- [x] Double group by `label` has regressed
Mostly on the actual formatting, it just hasn't been updated to new style
DONE https://github.com/diffgram/diffgram/pull/1275

- [ ] Exporting non-time series to CSV

- [ ] Testing

- [x] The by user drill down module is missing from Insights panel
- [ ] The difference between the Insights (per job) reporting, and the global reporting feels ill-defined. I think the technical side here doesn't need much work, more just documenting how it flows, like that one's "pre-filtered" to a specific view etc
- [ ] Documenting new dedicated reports. We have a variety of newish dedicated reports (like annotator performance, approve/reject etc). These are all good but just need to document them better. Each report maybe has it's own page briefly explaining the purpose behind it, what it includes/doesn't include, etc. It's one of those things that's obvious when we make it, but then time goes by. 

Please feel free to add other ideas on improving reporting and analytics
